recipe.title: Wilted Radicchio with Pangritata
recipe.description: The pangritata is a toasted garlic, herb and breadcrumb mixture which was originally known Southern Italy as 'poor man's parmesan' where it was used instead of parmesan cheese as a topping for pasta during learner times.
recipe.directions: Combine the breadcrumbs and herbs and mix well. In a frying pan, heat the olive oil on medium heat. Add the garlic and sauté for 30 seconds until fragrant. Add the breadcrumbs and toss well until they absorb the oil and garlic. Continue to cook over medium heat until the breadcrumb mixture has turned a golden brown colour. Wash the radicchio heads and slice an inch off the bottoms off each to remove the root and separate all the leaves. Pat dry with a paper towel. In a deep, wide sauté pan, heat the olive oil on medium-high. Add the radicchio leaves and toss with tongs until coated with the oil. Continue to cook, shaking the pan at regular intervals until all the leaves have darkened and wilted slightly. Add the pangritata to the pan containing the radicchio and toss well to mix. Remove to a large serving dish and add salt and pepper to taste. Serve warm. >
